questions.text: Read the following statements and answer accordingly- Sensitivity & Specificity of a screening test depends on the prevalence of disease in the population. questions.explanation:
Solution:

A & B are incorrect Sensitivity & Specificity are the basic parameters of validity. They are fixed parameters, i.e., the sensitivity & specificity of any test will not change in different types of settings. In other words, they are an intrinsic property of a screening test. The Predictive value of a screening test is largely dependent on the prevalence of the disease in the population in which the diagnostic test is being applied. As a general rule, the higher the prevalence of disease in the population, the higher will be the PPV. It, therefore, follows that it is best to apply a screening test in a population that has a high prevalence of disease because the PPV will be high and hence we will get a high yield. In general, the Sensitivity of a screening test is inversely proportional to the Specificity of the tes t. If sensitivity increases, then specificity decreases and vice-versa. Sensitivity of a screening test is the ability to identify correctly all those who are positives, i.e., true positives. Hence, sensitivity is directly proportional to True Positives. So, only C & D statements are correct.

The disease should be vaccine-preventable The disease to be screened should fulfill the following criteria before it is considered suitable for screening: The condition sought should be an important health problem (in general, prevalence should be high); There should be a recognizable latent or early asymptomatic stage; The natural history of the condition, including development from latent to declared disease, should be adequately understood (so that we can know at what stage the process ceases to be reversible); There is a test that can detect the disease before the onset of signs and symptoms; Facilities should be available for confirmation of the diagnosis; There is an effective treatment; There should be an agreed-on policy concerning whom to treat as patients (e.g., lower ranges of blood pressure; border-line diabetes) ; There is good evidence that early detection and treatment reduces morbidity and mortality; The expected benefits (e.g., the number of lives saved) of early detection exceed the risks and costs.

questions.text: All are the possible biases in screening programs EXCEPT-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Screening time bias Following biases are possible in screening programs- Lead Time Bias: If the early detection does not affect the course of the disease, then it will be like giving the patient a few more years of sickness and apprehension rather than health. This is called Lead Time Bias Length Time Bias: It has been observed that cases detected through a screening test tend to have a longer preclinical stage than those missed out by screening. This preclinical stage is defined as the interval between the time a screening test can detect a disease and the time the patient seeks care due to experiencing symptoms. Thus, length of time is a bias that tends to spuriously show better survival among screen-detected cases. Self-selection bias: If the group offered screening and others not offered screening are not constituted by random allocation but rather based on self-selection, such volunteers may be more health conscious, educated, and more likely to give up associated risk factors; hence survival in such a screened group is likely to be better, not due to screening, but because of associated factors. Berkesonian bias: is a type of bias that arises because of the different rates of admission to hospitals for people with different diseases, especially in case-control studies (i.e., hospital cases and controls).

Solution:

Sensitivity & 1-Specificity To decide the cut-off value for each screening test, we plot a curve known as the Receiver Operating Characteristic curve. Taking Sensitivity on the Y axis & corresponding value of 1-specificity on the X axis, all pairs of values are plotted for each cut-off. questions.text: Four different tests employed for the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus were evaluated in a study, as shown in the graph. Which of these tests would you consider as a better-performing test than others?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A The given graph shows the Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve, which evaluates the performance of a diagnostic test. They are useful for comparing the diagnostic ability of two or more screening tests or assessing the predictive ability of two or more biomarkers for the same disease. The different curve points correspond to the cutpoints used to determine whether the test results are positive or negative. The curve is obtained by joining the points represented by sensitivity and 1-specificity for the different cutpoints and the chance diagonal represented by the 45-degree line drawn through the coordinates (0,0) and (1,1). questions.text: The figure below shows a ROC curve for different cut-off points of a screening test. The area under the curve is 0.5. Which of the following statements is true-

options.label: A
options.text: The screening test has no discriminatory power

options.label: B
options.text: The sensitivity of the test is more than the specificity

options.label: C
options.text: Screening test has a high positive predictive value

questions.correct_answer: A. The screening test has no discriminatory power
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The screening test has no discriminatory power ROC curve here shows a straight line of 45 degrees corresponding to an area under the curve of 0.5, i.e., 50%. This indicates that the screening test has no discriminatory property and that the results are by pure chance. If the test is of any help to the decision maker, the points must lie above this diagonal line. This is so because if the test is useful, a positive decision should be more probable when the case is positive than when a case is negative. Therefore, the more the area under the curve, the better will be the overall discriminating ability of the test.

questions.text: The cut-off value of Fasting Blood Sugar for diagnosing a patient as diabetic is 126 mg/dl. Physicians want to improve the ability of this test to correctly identify those cases which are positive, so they will have to

options.label: C
options.text: Increase the number of tests conducted

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease the number of tests conducted

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decrease the set cut-off The ability of the screening test to correctly identify all those who have the disease is known as sensitivity. If a lower cut-off is chosen, very few diabetics would be misdiagnosed as normal that is, our false negative fraction would be reduced. Hence, the sensitivity will increase. However, a large proportion of non-diabetics may now be falsely labeled as ‘Diabetics’ i.e., the False positive fraction will be increased, which will ultimately reduce the specificity. So, by lowering the cut-off of the screening test, its sensitivity will increase but at the cost of specificity. In contrast, by increasing the cut-off, its specificity will increase but at the cost of sensitivity.

questions.text: A community physician started a screening program in an area to detect anemia in young women by estimating Blood hemoglobin levels. Females with Hb levels of 11 or less would be classified as frail. However, he wanted to be sure that all those who will be classified as frail by this test should be anemic. To fulfill this criterion, he should-

options.label: C
options.text: It will depend on the prevalence of anemia in that area

options.label: D
options.text: Increase the number of tests to be conducted

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increase the set cut-off By increasing the cut-off of blood hemoglobin level, many of the anemic patients may not be identified as having anemia now, on the other hand, most of the non-anemics will be correctly identified as negative. Those labelled as anemic after increasing the cut-off will be correctly identified as anemics. In other words, by increasing the cut-off, the false positive fraction will reduce, and the False negative fraction will increase. By increasing the cut-off, the physician will get less false positives, but he may miss outon many cases. Hence, by increasing the cut-off, the specificity of the test will improve but at the cost of sensitivity, whereas by lowering the cut-off of the screening test, it’s sensitivity will increase but at the cost of specificity.

To increase the sensitivity, we want the test to miss out on very few cases, i.e., false negatives. questions.text: The figure here shows a graphical representation of Normal & Diseased persons classified based on a screening test whose cut-off has been fixed at the point shown by the central line. questions.text: The figure above shows the graphical representation of Hypertensives and Normotensives identified with the help of two different BP measuring instruments. Choose the most appropriate response concerning the Validity of the BP measuring instruments-

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sensitivity & Specificity of instrument 2 is more than instrument 1 As is clear from this figure that both the False Negatives and False positives are decreased while measuring BP from Instrument two as compared to Instrument 1. Sensitivity = TP ÷ (TP + FN), since FN has decreased on using instrument two as compared to instrument 1, therefore instrument 2 has more sensitivity. Specificity = TN ÷ (TN + FP), since FP has decreased on using instrument two as compared to instrument 1, therefore, instrument 2 has more specificity. So, Specificity & Sensitivity both are more in Instrument 2 as compared to Instrument 1. A good test should have both high sensitivity and specificity.

questions.text: The advantage gained by early detection through screening tests rather than routine diagnostic tests is-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lead time Lead time is defined as the interval between the point a condition is detected through screening and the time it would usually have been detected due to the appearance and reporting of signs and symptoms. It is the advantage gained by early detection through a screening test rather than a routine diagnostic test. Length time: It has been observed that cases detected through a screening test tend to have a longer preclinical stage than those missed out by screening. This preclinical stage is defined as the interval between the time a screening test can detect a disease and the time the patient seeks care due to experiencing symptoms. Thus, length of time is a bias that tends to show a better survival among screen-detected cases spuriously.

questions.text: The figure shows a model for early detection programs through screening. ‘Lead time’ is depicted between points-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B & D The figure here shows the possible outcomes for a given disease process. After the onset of diseases, several critical points usually determine both the severity of the disease and the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. Label 'B' shows the first possible point for detecting the disease. Label 'C' shows the final critical point to which screening can detect the disease. Label 'D' shows the usual time when a diagnostic test would detect the disease. ‘Lead time' is the advantage gained by screening, i.e., the period between early detection and diagnosis by other means. So, the period between points B & D here depicts the advantage gained by screening, that is Lead time.

questions.text: The Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve for the diagnosis of glaucoma is shown in the following figure. The area under the curve is 0.81. The correct interpretation is-

options.label: A
options.text: 81% of the subjects have been diagnosed correctly by the diagnostic test.

options.label: B
options.text: The probability that the test result will be positive is 81%

options.label: C
options.text: The diagnostic test is of little credibility.

questions.correct_answer: A. 81% of the subjects have been diagnosed correctly by the diagnostic test.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

81% of the subjects have been diagnosed correctly by the diagnostic test. Area under the ROC curve (AUC) is an effective way to summarize the overall diagnostic accuracy of the test. It corresponds to the proportion of a total number of possible pairs of truly diseased and truly non-diseased subjects, in which the truly diseased subject has been assigned a higher probability of having the disease. Area under the curve for this diagnostic test is 0.81 or 81%, which means in 81% of the pairs, the probability of having the disease is higher in truly diseased than those not having the disease. In other words, 81% of the subjects have been diagnosed correctly by the diagnostic test. In general, an AUC of 0.5 suggests no discrimination ability (as it will fall on the diagonal line corresponding to the coordinates 0,0 & 1,1). AUC of 0.7 to 0.8 is considered acceptable, 0.8 to 0.9 is considered excellent, and more than 0.9 is considered outstanding. ROC is the best way to predict diagnostic accuracy.

questions.text: A man diagnosed with metastatic lung cancer at 69 years died when he is 70 years old. Another man diagnosed with the same condition at 65 years and not treated died at 70 years. The man diagnosed earlier seems to have survived for more years compared to the man diagnosed later. This is an example of
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lead time bias It is the apparent increase in survival time due to early diagnosis by screening In the given question, a man who was diagnosed with metastatic lung cancer at 69 years died at 70 years, and the other man diagnosed with the same at 65 years also died at 70 years. But the survival time of a man diagnosed earlier appears to have increased compared to the other. This is referred to as the lead time bias.
